title: Essential Documents: Stay Legal and Organised
summary: Understand the paperwork and processes that keep you legally on the road and ready for checks or emergencies.

sections.title: Why Documents Matter
sections.body: Keeping your documents up to date proves you’re entitled to drive, insured, and operating a roadworthy vehicle. It also makes roadside or insurance checks stress-free.

sections.title: DVSA Essentials
items: You must have a valid provisional or full driving licence to drive on public roads.
Vehicles over three years old need a valid MOT certificate.
You must be insured to drive the vehicle, and it must be taxed (Vehicle Excise Duty).

sections.title: Key Documents
items: Driving licence photocard—check the expiry date and address details.
Insurance certificate or digital proof—know who you’re insured to drive and any excesses.
MOT certificate (if applicable) and service history.
V5C log book for the vehicle owner showing registered keeper details.

sections.title: When Things Change
items: Update the DVLA if you change name or address.
Tell your insurer about vehicle modifications or new main drivers.
SORN (Statutory Off Road Notification) a vehicle if you stop using it on public roads.
Replace lost or damaged documents promptly to avoid fines.

sections.title: Proving Roadworthiness
sections.body: Keep a digital and paper copy of maintenance receipts. They help when selling the vehicle or dealing with insurance claims after a collision.

checklist.label: My driving licence details are current and stored safely.
I know where to access my insurance certificate instantly.
My vehicle has a valid MOT (if required) and I track the renewal date.
I know how to update DVLA and insurers if my circumstances change.

practiceTips.label: Build a folder
practiceTips.detail: Create a shared digital folder for your licence, insurance, MOT, and breakdown cover. Share access with your supervising driver.

practiceTips.label: Theo’s renewal reminders
practiceTips.detail: Add MOT, tax, and insurance renewal dates to your calendar with alerts one month in advance.

practiceTips.label: Mock roadside stop
practiceTips.detail: Role-play being asked for documents. Practise explaining where they’re stored and how you’d show them within seven days at a police station.

questions.prompt: Which document proves who is responsible for taxing and registering a vehicle?

options.label: Insurance certificate
options.explanation: Insurance proves financial cover, not registered keeper details.

options.label: V5C registration certificate
options.explanation: The V5C shows the registered keeper and vehicle details.

options.label: MOT certificate
options.explanation: MOT proves roadworthiness, not ownership.

options.label: Purchase receipt
options.explanation: A sales receipt is useful but the V5C is the DVLA’s official record of the keeper.

questions.prompt: Your licence address changes. How soon must you inform the DVLA?

options.label: Within 6 months
options.explanation: Waiting risks fines and important mail going to the wrong address.

options.label: Immediately or as soon as possible
options.explanation: Updating quickly keeps your record accurate and avoids penalties.

options.label: Only when you renew the licence
options.explanation: You must update your address straight away, not wait for renewal.

options.label: When you next buy a vehicle
options.explanation: Address changes must be reported immediately, regardless of vehicle purchases.

options.label: Declaring a vehicle off the road so you don’t need to tax or insure it
options.explanation: SORN stops you being charged vehicle tax while it’s off the road.

options.label: Renewing your MOT
options.explanation: MOT renewal is a separate process.

options.label: Changing your driving instructor
options.explanation: SORN is about the vehicle, not instructors.

options.label: Booking a practical test
options.explanation: Test bookings are unrelated to declaring a vehicle off the road.

questions.prompt: How long do you usually have to produce documents at a police station if requested by an officer?

options.label: 7 days
options.explanation: You normally have seven days to present documents if you can’t show them roadside.

options.label: 24 hours
options.explanation: 24 hours is not the standard time allowed.

options.label: Until the next MOT
options.explanation: You must present documents promptly—waiting for the MOT isn’t acceptable.

options.label: Whenever you can get a lift to the station
options.explanation: The law expects you to present documents within the stated seven-day period.

questions.prompt: What is the minimum insurance cover you must have before driving on public roads?

options.label: Third-party cover
options.explanation: UK law requires at least third-party insurance to cover injury or damage you cause to others.

options.label: Third-party, fire and theft
options.explanation: This offers extra protection but the legal minimum is third-party cover.

options.label: Comprehensive cover
options.explanation: Fully comprehensive is optional; it isn’t the legal minimum.

options.label: No insurance if you only drive occasionally
options.explanation: Every vehicle used or kept on public roads must be insured unless it has a valid SORN.
